Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned that daily dedication to language is the only effective way to learn it well.
Chinese 110 definitely focuses on constant exposure to written and spoken forms of Mandarin. That constant exposure has made me more comfortable in reading, writing, and speaking Chinese.
a whole lot of chinese. More than I expected.
I learned about Chinese culture and formed the basis of conversational Chinese.
I believe I learned how to come communicate in Chinese at a basic level quite we'll. My listening, writing, and speaking skills in Chinese have improved considerably by taking this course

I really strengthened my Chinese, and did a great deal of expanding my vocab.  I also started to pick up on the tones (which we pretty much just ignored in high school, and the moment when I stopped having to pay attention to each individual tone and started doing it more as second nature was insanely satisfying.
Learned basics of Chinese
I learned basic Chinese phrases and many characters.
Besides learning the Chinese language, I also learned about the Chinese culture and its customs.

The program seems very well put together, as though the kinks have been worked out slowly over time. It requires a lot of dedication, especially memorizing dialogues, but I agree that this kind of memorization really helps students remember what they need to. If I had to suggest something for improvement, I would say that perhaps encouraging more outside of class activities so that students new to Chinese might be able to meet the Chinese community at Yale better.
The great thing about Chinese 110 is that it forces students to be constantly engaged with the language by having daily quizzes and weekly assignments like passage memorization or speaking with a TA.
The quizzes were annoying, but really forced you to prepare. This course requires a lot outside of the classroom, but it's pretty much effort-in effort out.
The immersive class time is wonderful. The only change would be regarding the oral test. I often felt I got questions wrong just because I didn't understand the computer.

The course really helped build a working Chinese vocabulary--I feel as though I can handle myself in a pretty good number of situations, which I'm super happy with given how short the course was.  I really enjoyed how we rotated between professors, since I feel like we were able to build meaningful relationships with all of them. The course's organizational structure was a little confusing at first (there's a website and two different canvas courses that we receive information from) but that was mostly in the first couple weeks of the course and I feel like it wouldn't be a problem going forward.  I wish there was a way we could have more/longer conversations, since I feel like using the language dynamically instead of following a script really helped me.  Overall, though, I thought it was a fine class.
The teachers made sure we were very engaged and involved in class. However, I did not necessarily have a great experience with my TA in terms of learning Chinese.
The its course's quick pace is both its strength and downfall. While you definitely learn the language, if you do not keep up, you can quickly fall behind.

I would highly recommend the Chinese language program to anyone seeking a language fulfillment requirement or just wanting to learn a new language in general. All of the  put a a lot of effort into the class, and although it can be a lot at times, they understand and help as much as they can.
Absolutely, Chinese is a very useful language and it's taught very well here.
If you want to take Chinese, take this course.
Yes, an excellent introduction to chinese.

Yes, the although the course was difficult, I felt that I learned a very great amount in the short time that I had. The instructors were great and everyone in the class was engaged throughout the entire semester.
Yes, the Chinese program at Yale is much more vigorous than at other institutions.
I would highly recommend the course to anyone that wants to start learning Chinese.

I'd absolutely recommend this course!  I had a great time, feel like I learned a bunch, and really enjoyed our professors.  Taking Chinese was a blast, and if you're looking to fill your language credit, I think this is the place to be.
Yes very useful
Yes, it teaches you Chinese very well.
Take it if you have a real reason to learn Chinese.
Yes!
